title: CVPR_2008_258_abs

sentences.text: We propose a novel step toward the unsupervised seg-mentation of whole objects by combining '' hints '' of partial scene segmentation offered by multiple soft , binary mattes .
These mattes are implied by a set of hypothesized object boundary fragments in the scene .
Rather than trying to find or define a single '' best '' segmentation , we generate multiple segmentations of an image .

This reflects contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery from groups of images , and it allows us to define intuitive evaluation met-rics for our sets of segmentations based on the accurate and parsimonious delineation of scene objects .
Our proposed approach builds on recent advances in spectral clustering , image matting , and boundary detection .
It is demonstrated qualitatively and quantitatively on a dataset of scenes and is suitable for current work in unsupervised object discovery without top-down knowledge .

summary: We propose a novel step toward the unsupervised seg-mentation of whole objects by combining '' hints '' of partial scene segmentation offered by multiple soft , binary mattes . These mattes are implied by a set of hypothesized object boundary fragments in the scene . Rather than trying to find or define a single '' best '' segmentation , we generate multiple segmentations of an image . This reflects contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery from groups of images , and it allows us to define intuitive evaluation met-rics for our sets of segmentations based on the accurate and parsimonious delineation of scene objects . Our proposed approach builds on recent advances in spectral clustering , image matting , and boundary detection . It is demonstrated qualitatively and quantitatively on a dataset of scenes and is suitable for current work in unsupervised object discovery without top-down knowledge .
kg2text: Our proposed approach integrates hints from partial scene segmentation, which is a technique that assists in the unsupervised segmentation of whole objects. This approach generates multiple segmentations, reflecting contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery from groups of images. A novel step within this methodology combines multiple soft, binary mattes, which are derived from hypothesized object boundary fragments, to enhance the segmentation process. Furthermore, partial scene segmentation is a broader term that encompasses the general concept of segmentation. The multiple soft, binary mattes also fall under the broader category of mattes. Our proposed approach builds on several foundational techniques, including boundary detection, recent advances in spectral clustering, and image matting, all of which contribute to the effectiveness of current work in unsupervised object discovery. This work is part of contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery, which aim to identify and segment objects without relying on predefined labels or top-down knowledge.

Multiple segmentations, which refer to the generation of various possible segmentations of an image, have a broader term known as segmentation. Contemporary methods for unsupervised object discovery from groups of images allow for the creation of sets of segmentations, reflecting the principles of unsupervised object discovery. These methods build on techniques such as spectral clustering, which has seen recent advances that enhance its application in segmentation tasks. Sets of segmentations are based on the accurate and parsimonious delineation of scene objects, which are crucial for identifying distinct scene objects within an image. Additionally, groups of images serve as a broader category that encompasses images used in these methods. The dataset of scenes, which is demonstrated on various scenes, is a structured collection that aids in evaluating these segmentation approaches and is part of the broader dataset category.
